lines.text: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and PARIS

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: On Thursday, sir the time is very short.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: My father Capulet will have it so And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: You say you do not know the ladys mind: Uneven is the course, I like it not.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Immoderately she weeps for Tybalts death, And therefore have I little talkd of love For Venus smiles not in a house of tears. Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous That she doth give her sorrow so much sway, And in his wisdom hastes our marriage, To stop the inundation of her tears Which, too much minded by herself alone, May be put from her by society: Now do you know the reason of this haste.

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: [Aside]  I would I knew not why it should be slowd. Look, sir, here comes the lady towards my cell.
Enter JULIET

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Happily met, my lady and my wife!

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: That may be must be, love, on Thursday next.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: What must be shall be.

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: Thats a certain text.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Come you to make confession to this father

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: To answer that, I should confess to you.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Do not deny to him that you love me.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: I will confess to you that I love him.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: If I do so, it will be of more price, Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: The tears have got small victory by that For it was bad enough before their spite.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Thou wrongst it, more than tears, with that report.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: That is no slander, sir, which is a truth And what I spake, I spake it to my face.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slanderd it.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: It may be so, for it is not mine own. Are you at leisure, holy father, now Or shall I come to you at evening mass

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now. My lord, we must entreat the time alone.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: God shield I should disturb devotion! Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye: Till then, adieu and keep this holy kiss.
Exit

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: O shut the door! and when thou hast done so, Come weep with me past hope, past cure, past help!

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: Ah, Juliet, I already know thy grief It strains me past the compass of my wits: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it, On Thursday next be married to this county.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Tell me not, friar, that thou hearst of this, Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it: If, in thy wisdom, thou canst give no help, Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this knife Ill help it presently. God joind my heart and Romeos, thou our hands And ere this hand, by thee to Romeo seald, Shall be the label to another deed, Or my true heart with treacherous revolt Turn to another, this shall slay them both: Therefore, out of thy longexperienced time, Give me some present counsel, or, behold, Twixt my extremes and me this bloody knife Shall play the umpire, arbitrating that Which the commission of thy years and art Could to no issue of true honour bring. Be not so long to speak I long to die, If what thou speakst speak not of remedy.

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: Hold, daughter: I do spy a kind of hope, Which craves as desperate an execution. As that is desperate which we would prevent. If, rather than to marry County Paris, Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself, Then is it likely thou wilt undertake A thing like death to chide away this shame, That copest with death himself to scape from it: And, if thou darest, Ill give thee remedy.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris, From off the battlements of yonder tower Or walk in thievish ways or bid me lurk Where serpents are chain me with roaring bears Or shut me nightly in a charnelhouse, Oercoverd quite with dead mens rattling bones, With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls Or bid me go into a newmade grave And hide me with a dead man in his shroud Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble And I will do it without fear or doubt, To live an unstaind wife to my sweet love.

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: Hold, then go home, be merry, give consent To marry Paris: Wednesday is tomorrow: Tomorrow night look that thou lie alone Let not thy nurse lie with thee in thy chamber: Take thou this vial, being then in bed, And this distilled liquor drink thou off When presently through all thy veins shall run A cold and drowsy humour, for no pulse Shall keep his native progress, but surcease: No warmth, no breath, shall testify thou livest The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade To paly ashes, thy eyes windows fall, Like death, when he shuts up the day of life Each part, deprived of supple government, Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death: And in this borrowd likeness of shrunk death Thou shalt continue two and forty hours, And then awake as from a pleasant sleep. Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead: Then, as the manner of our country is, In thy best robes uncoverd on the bier Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie. In the mean time, against thou shalt awake, Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift, And hither shall he come: and he and I Will watch thy waking, and that very night Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua. And this shall free thee from this present shame If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear, Abate thy valour in the acting it.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Give me, give me! O, tell not me of fear!

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: Hold get you gone, be strong and prosperous In this resolve: Ill send a friar with speed To Mantua, with my letters to thy lord.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Love give me strength! and strength shall help afford. Farewell, dear father!
Exeunt
